DOCNAME: CASE OF CSERJÉS AND OTHERS v. HUNGARY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Reasonable time)
TEXT: CARDINAL . Upon a private company ’s request , in DATE PERSON , a forest engineer employed by the company , made an estimation of the amount of damages caused to the company ’s territory by wild animals under the responsibility of a hunting society . Subsequently , on DATE the company brought an action in compensation against the hunting society , the members of which were the applicants .
CARDINAL . In DATE the hunting society was dissolved . The proceedings were discontinued on DATE , pending the identification of successors to the proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE the proceedings continued , as the plaintiff designated the applicants as successors to the proceedings .
CARDINAL . ORG appointed an expert , PERSON , to establish the value of the hunters’ house . The expert filed an opinion on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found for the plaintiff . This judgment was quashed by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . In the resumed proceedings , due to the bias declared by the judges in GPE , the case was heard by ORG . The court requested PERSON to submit a further expert report to establish the amount of damages caused . He filed an opinion on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first - instance court gave judgment , finding for the plaintiff . The applicants appealed , arguing - among others - that they had not received the copy of TIME of the hearing of DATE on time , and questioning the impartiality of PERSON

CARDINAL . On appeal , ORG upheld ORG judgment . Concerning TIME of the hearing , the second - instance court pointed out that ORG had no legal obligation to send them the minutes automatically . They had the options of requesting copies either by post or in person at the court . The applicants had requested the copies for the first time on DATE , following which the court had sent the minutes on DATE despite the fact that the applicants had not paid the copy fees . The delivery of the mail sent according to the rules had not been successful . Following the repeated request of the applicants on DATE , the copies had been sent once again on DATE . Moreover , the court pointed out that the respondents had been present at the hearing , where they had the opportunity to take notes , and could have submitted observations within DATE to PERSON expert report , delivered to them on DATE . As to the impartiality of PERSON , the court emphasised that he had been the only expert to see the damages on - site in DATE . DATE after the occurrence of the damages , appointing a further forensic expert to proceed on the basis of documentary evidence would have been futile in the court ’s opinion . In addition , PERSON had followed the court ’s instructions when preparing the expert report .
CARDINAL . The applicants lodged a petition for review with ORG , which upheld the final judgment on DATE . This decision was served on the applicants on DATE .
